The following are the recommended land preparation practices for tomato production:

  • Plow the area 2-3 times, one month before transplanting. \

  • Harrow twice to break the clods, level the field, and pulverize the soil to promote good aeration, enhance root formation and facilitate planting.

  • Prepare raised-bed for conventional tillage in flat upland during the wet season.

  • Practice zero tillage in sloping hills and sand dunes
Transplanting is the common method of establishment for tomato. The following are the recommended crop establishment practices for tomato.

• Sow seeds in boxes or plastic trays with sterilized soil medium (garden soil, carbonized rice hull and compost at 1:1:1 ratio).

  • Select an open area with sufficient windbreaks during the wet season, if seedbed is used.

  • Use soil with high organic matter content or completely decomposed organic wastes.

  • Ensure that the area is free or protected from animals and near a water source. 

  • Prepare slightly depressed beds during the wet season. 

  • Sow the seeds thinly and evenly and sprinkler water over the seedbed.

• Water the seedlings thoroughly a day before transplanting to facilitate uprooting and avoid too much injury.

  • Transplant one seedling per hill preferably in the afternoon to minimize seedling mortality, 20 to 30 days after sowing. 

  • Make furrow in a well pulverized soil using animal drawn moldboard plow at 1 to 1.25 m distance between rows and 0.5 m between double rows.

  • Irrigate furrows and transplant directly to the soil at 0.4 m between hills.

  • Transplant seedlings in raised beds during wet season at a distance of 0.40 m between hills and 1.0-1.25 m between rows.
Use of trellis is highly recommended during wet season. This will prevent the fruits from touching the soil/ground which can result to rotting.

The following are the recommended nutrient management practices for tomato production:

  • Apply organic fertilizer at 40 bags per hectare.

  • Use complete (14-14-14) fertilizer at 8 bags/ha basally.

Side dress 4 bags urea (46-0-0) and 2 bags muriate of potash (0-0-60) per hectare at 3 to 4 weeks after transplanting.
